sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
A supplement to a late treatise, called An essay for the discovery of some new geometrical problems concerning angular sections, resolving what was there problematically proposed; and with some rectification made in the former essay, showing an easie method truly geometrical, without any conick section, or cubick æquation, to sect any angle or arch of a circle into 3. 5. 7. or any other uneven number of equal parts. By G. K. Keith, George, 1639?-1716.
7, [1] p.
printed for the author, and are to be had at the Three Pigeons over against the Exchange, and at his House in Pudding-lane, at the sign of the Golden Ball, where he teacheth the mathematical arts, [London : [1697?]]
G.K. = George Keith. Caption title. Imprint from colophon; publication date conjectured by Wing. Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
=======
A supplement to a late treatise, called An essay for the discovery of some new geometrical problems concerning angular sections, resolving what was there problematically proposed; and with some rectification made in the former essay, showing an easie method truly geometrical, without any conick section, or cubick æquation, to sect any angle or arch of a circle into 3. 5. 7. or any other uneven number of equal parts. By G. K. Keith, George, 1639?-1716.
7, [1] p.
printed for the author, and are to be had at the Three Pigeons over against the Exchange, and at his House in Pudding-lane, at the sign of the Golden Ball, where he teacheth the mathematical arts, [London : [1697?]]
G.K. = George Keith. Caption title. Imprint from colophon; publication date conjectured by Wing. Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
